algorithms.name: create segment endpoints for a gap
algorithms.html: To <dfn class="dfn-paneled has-dfn-panel" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-noexport="" id="create-segment-endpoints-for-a-gap" role="button" aria-expanded="false" tabindex="0">create segment endpoints for a gap</dfn> <var>G</var>:

steps.html:
Bounds of a Gap:

Create endpoints at G’s two bounds:

  • At the centerpoint of G’s start edge, create a start segment endpoint.
  • At the centerpoint of G’s end edge, create an end segment endpoint.

Within a Gap:

A gap junction is a region of G where one or more gaps abut or overlap G. Two segment endpoints are created for each gap junction:

  • Entering a gap junction: At the point where a cross gap appears on at least one side of G, create an end segment endpoint.
  • Exiting a gap junction: At the point where no cross gap exists on either side of G, create a start segment endpoint.

algorithms.name: determine the gap decoration segments
algorithms.html: To determine the gap decoration segments for a given gap G:

steps.html: Let S, the collection of gap decoration segments for G, be an empty list.
Let endpoints be the list of all segment endpoints created for G, ordered by their position along the centerline from start to end.

While endpoints is not empty:
  • Let u be the first segment endpoint in endpoints, and remove it from the list.
  • Let v be the first segment endpoint in endpoints, and remove it from the list.
  • Create a new gap decoration segment starting at u and ending at v.
  • Append the new segment to S.
Return <var>S</var>.

algorithms.name: determine painted segments
algorithms.html: To <dfn class="dfn-paneled has-dfn-panel" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-noexport="" id="determine-painted-segments" role="button" aria-expanded="false" tabindex="0">determine painted segments</dfn> <var>C</var> from segments list <var>S</var>:

steps.html: Let S be the list of segments determined for the given gap, ordered from start to end along the gap’s axis.
Let <var>C</var> be an empty list of segments.
Let break be the used value of either column-rule-break or row-rule-break, whichever applies to the gap.
If <var>S</var> is empty, return <var>C</var>.
If break is none:
Let <var>first</var> be the first segment in <var>S</var>.
Let <var>last</var> be the last segment in <var>S</var>.
Let segment be UNION(first, last).
Apply offsets to segment, then append it to C.
Return <var>C</var>.
Remove the first segment from <var>S</var>. Let <var>s</var> be that segment.
If s’s endpoints are discontiguous, go back to step 4.
If <var>S</var> is not empty:
Let <var>next</var> be the first segment in <var>S</var>.
Let candidate be UNION(s, next).
If candidate’s endpoints are discontiguous, go to step 9.
If break is intersection and candidate is not flanked by spanning items, go to step 9.
Remove the first segment from <var>S</var>.
Set s to UNION(s, next).
Go back to step 8.
Apply offsets to s, then append it to C.
Go back to step 4.

algorithms.name: apply offsets to a segment
algorithms.html: To <dfn class="dfn-paneled has-dfn-panel" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-lt="apply offsets to a segment" data-noexport="" id="apply-offsets-to-a-segment" role="button" aria-expanded="false" tabindex="0">apply offsets to a segment </dfn> for a given segment <var>s</var> = [<var>start</var>, <var>end</var>]:

steps.html: Compute the offset for start within gap. Offset start by the result, in the forward direction along gap’s axis.
Compute the offset for end within gap. Offset end by the result, in the reverse direction along gap’s axis.
Update <var>s</var> with the adjusted [<var>start</var>, <var>end</var>].

algorithms.name: compute the offset
algorithms.html: To compute the offset for a given segment endpoint point within a given gap:

steps.html: Let width be the crossing gap width for point.
Let inset be the computed value of either column-rule-inset or row-rule-inset, whichever applies to gap. Resolve any percentages in inset against width.

Let <var>result</var> be <var>width</var> multiplied by 50%.
				Add <var>inset</var> to <var>result</var>.
Return <var>result</var>.

algorithms.name: assign gap decoration values
algorithms.html: To <dfn class="dfn-paneled has-dfn-panel" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-noexport="" id="assign-gap-decoration-values" role="button" aria-expanded="false" tabindex="0">assign gap decoration values</dfn> to a list of <var>gaps</var> using a list of <var>values</var>:

steps.html: Replace any integer repeaters in values with their expanded-out equivalents.
If the list contains no auto repeater, then:

Beginning from the first item in <var>values</var> and the first item in <var>gaps</var>,
						assign each value to the corresponding gap.
						If there are fewer values than gaps,
						repeat beginning from the first item in <var>values</var>,
						as many times as needed.
End this algorithm.
values contains an auto repeater. Let leading count be the number of items in values before the auto repeater. Let trailing count be the number of items in values after the auto repeater.
Partition <var>gaps</var> as follows:
Let <var>leading gaps</var> contain the first <var>leading count</var> items in <var>gaps</var>.

Let <var>trailing gaps</var> contain the last <var>trailing count</var> items in <var>gaps</var>,
						excluding any items in <var>leading gaps</var>.

Let <var>auto gaps</var> contain any items in <var>gaps</var>
						that are not in either <var>leading gaps</var> or <var>trailing gaps</var>.
If leading gaps is non-empty, assign gap decoration values to leading gaps using the first leading count items in values.
If trailing gaps is non-empty, assign gap decoration values to trailing gaps using the first trailing count items in values.
If auto gaps is non-empty, assign gap decoration values to auto gaps using the list of values in the second argument of the auto repeater.

algorithms.name: interpolate with auto repeaters
algorithms.html: When either of the lists we are interpolating between (from and to) include an auto repeater:

steps.html: Split each of from and to into segments, similar to how we assign gap decoration values:
Let leading values be the values before the auto repeater.
Let trailing values be the values after the auto repeater.
Let auto values be the values inside the auto repeater.
If only one of from or to contains an auto-repeater, we fall back to discrete interpolation.
Expand any integer repeaters on each segment.

If the length of leading values in from and leading values in to don’t match, we fall back to discrete interpolation. If the length of trailing values in from and trailing values in to don’t match, we fall back to discrete interpolation.
When both from and to contain auto-repeaters, and the length of their segments match as described above, apply repeatable list interpolation to the lists of values in each auto values.

algorithms.name: repeater aligned
algorithms.html:
The longhands are <dfn class="dfn-paneled has-dfn-panel" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-noexport="" id="repeater-aligned" role="button" aria-expanded="false" tabindex="0">repeater aligned</dfn>
	if and only if all of the following are true:

steps.html: <var>W</var>, <var>S</var> and <var>C</var> have the same number of items.
For each item index <var>i</var>, <var>W</var>[<var>i</var>], <var>S</var>[<var>i</var>] and <var>C</var>[<var>i</var>] all have the same shape:
they are either all non-repeat values, all integer repeaters, or all auto repeaters.
If they are integer repeaters, the <integer> values are equal.
Each repeat() notation contains the same number of values.
